To solve the Ornstein–Uhlenbeck (OU) SDE: instead of assuming X_t = f(B_t, t), which works for the GMB but not for the OU, you may try: X_t = f(B_t, t, \int_0^t g(s) dB_s). Denoting the variables as f(z, t, y) you will then find, by matching terms as you did for the GMB, that f_z must be constant (hence, f_zz must be zero, and then f_z = 0 turns out to be feasible), then, you will find, using the dt term, f = exp(-\mu t) (y + x_0) where y = \int_0^t g(s) dB_s. After this, you can find g(s) by matching the dB_t term. Done 😊

33:09 I think there is a crucial link between option pricing and finite difference method that Dr. Lee didn't explicitly state. Remember your good old Black-Scholes equation? That's a PDE that governs the option price! You can definitely use finite difference method on the Black-Scholes PDE to price options. Although it's a bit silly to do so because we can often derive the closed-form pricing formula for derivatives (even some exotic ones) under the Black-Scholes model. But for some really weird path-dependent ones, this is for sure one way to go.  However, the real power of this technique lies in one observation: Even for models that are more complex than Black-Scholes, we can often write down a PDE that governs the option prices under those models. More remarkably, those PDEs are often of the same form as the Black-Scholes PDE. For example, there is a similar PDE under the Heston model, which is one of the many stochastic volatility models out there, and the channel quantpie has a video about the derivation of that PDE.  What all of this means is that you can still use finite difference method under these advanced models to price exotic derivatives, which is pretty cool imo.

The topic was Calculus of Variations and its Application in FX Execution. See http://ocw.mit.edu/18-S096F13 for more info and materials. Best wishes on your studies!
@mitocw  oh nice, thanks for the response

Yes, numerical approximations form a large part of the applied part of quant finance, especially as computational power has grown exponentially. I also think continuous models are overglorified due to their elegance; however, we often push aside the fact that real markets and prices are discrete in both space and time.  I presume you have read Daniel Duffy's work on FDM in C++ (if not it is a great overview of FDM - he has other more specialised books on the topic too). I like the general algorithm of firstly creating a PDE based on a financial model; next, approximating the PDE via FDM; Finally, implementing the FDM to C++/other language code. Also you say that we can derive closed-form prices - I presume you mean for European options only? If not I would appreciate expansion on this point as I may be missing something. Thank you.

38:04 40:26 Just to extend their explanation a bit more, tree method is heavily used to price path-dependent options, as they often don't have close-form solution (depending both on the product and the model), and by its nature the whole price path might be required, unlike the vanilla European options.   A good example would be American style put, since it is well-known that there is no analytical solution for its price, we have no choice but to resort to some sort of tree method (or Monte Carlo simulation) to do the pricing.

6:54 Just a side note, for GBM, there is actually another easy way to solve it. If we consider f(t,X_t) = ln(X_t), then we can apply Ito's lemma and you will see that all the "X_t" will be isolated on the LHS, which means we can now integrate both sides and get the exact same answer as shown in the video.

He's differentiating Xt through the second order term which is the quadratic variation (Ito) term.  Brownian Motion  has unbounded total variation, but it also does have bounded quadratic variation, which is the foundation of Ito Calculus.  Keep in mind that the SDE's are only mathematically meaningful and defined in the integral form. This in terms of convergence and taking the sums to a limit in the rigorous proof of Ito's Lemma.
